video.title: Chasm and This Is The Police 2 (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text:
Yep, it&#39;s still drought season, in both gaming
and California.

Sorry to keep mentioning it but you might
need context if you&#39;re watching this video
on the sexteenth of funvember or something.

So in lieu of having saved up enough morphine
tablets here&#39;re two more indie games on Steam.

And I&#39;ll even think of a connection between
them if you give me a mo - they&#39;re both about

some kind of peacekeeping official having
to rescue some things and murder some other

things - oh fuck it let&#39;s just go with &quot;they
both bored the tits off me.&quot;
Let&#39;s start with Chasm.

It&#39;s pixel art, it&#39;s procedural, it&#39;s metroidvania,
and of course it&#39;s fucking Kickstarted.

Hey, Kickstarter backers, don&#39;t insulate the
inside of that comfort zone too much, there&#39;ll
be no room for your fat spotty arse.

We are a rookie knight despatched to an abandoned
mining town to figure out what&#39;s gone wrong,

and upon taking a look in the mine he goes
&quot;Well there&#39;s your problem, you&#39;ve got a Metroidvania
game down there.

Five distinct zones opened up in stages by
new abilities, boss fights, more backtracking

than a mistakenly laid out railway... that&#39;s
Metroidvania, alright, hope you&#39;ve been maintaining

that save point in your town square &#39;cos this
is gonna cost yer, madam.&quot;

Castlevania seems like the main influence,
rescuing individual villagers is straight

out of Order of Ecclesia and there&#39;s a friendly
animate sword NPC you can get that made the

60% of my brain devoted to remembering things
from Symphony of the Night light up like Blackpool

pier, but while Alucard could reasonably be
expected to take on Dracula&#39;s minions &#39;cos

he ate asses for breakfast, the spotty gimp
we control here doesn&#39;t inspire the same confidence,

and the only thing that&#39;s changed by the time
we fight the formless unstoppable demon king

of the underworld at the end is that he found
a nicer sword and some running shoes.

Also, Chasm is procedurally generated, or
at least that&#39;s the claim.

It seems like the boss fights, the warp rooms
and the upgrades are all roughly in fixed

order and it&#39;s just all the filler rooms in
between that change, but I&#39;m not even 100%
on that.

I started a second game with a new seed to
see if I could figure out what had changed,

and discovered a short ways in that I didn&#39;t
actually give a shit.

Mind you, Castlevania and randomization has
a precedent.

I&#39;ve played Aria of Sorrow so many times I&#39;ve
tried using fanmade ROM randomizers to swap

all the pickups around and inject a little
variety into my next playthrough,

but what usually ended up happening was that
a starting skeleton would drop the fucking

Claimh Solais or something and I&#39;d spend the
rest of the game effortlessly handing out
wedgies.

Maybe that&#39;s why Chasm&#39;s gameplay challenge
seems painfully unbalanced, but I think it
was mainly because of the magic daggers.

See, magic attacks are upgradable and you
can equip whichever one you want, and once

fully upgraded the magic daggers were doing
between 60 and shitloads of damage a pop and
still only cost one point to use.

So I ended up spamming them like it was fuckin&#39;
Gradius and killed every single boss in the
game&#39;s second half on my first go.
Often without getting hit.

I did at least finish the game, but only because
it took basically no effort and I had some
podcasts to listen to.

And while procedural generation theoretically
adds replay value, I&#39;d far rather replay a

game that carefully crafts its layout for
maximum entertainment, than a game like Chasm

which rearranges its dull generic hallways
full of repeated enemies in a way that has

all the practical impact of rearranging the
contents of a bag of frozen oven chips.

I can state that Chasm is the very best game
I&#39;ve played named Chasm.

It is at least better than Chasm: The Rift,
because in contrast it&#39;s a generic Castlevania

ripoff with some nice pixel art rather than
a generic Quake ripoff with the colour spectrum
of a turd convention.

So let&#39;s move on to our second game, which
I didn&#39;t actually finish but am going to offer

a definitive opinion on anyway because I&#39;m
a busy man with a lot of uneaten crisps in
the house: This Is The Police 2.

I haven&#39;t played This Is The Police 1 so I
had no idea what I was in for but I was drawn
to the fact that the acronym was Titper.

This Is The Police 2 it turns out is a game
structured somewhat like X-COM, with isometric

turn-based cover combat missions interspersed
with a management game where you equip and

dispatch named officers to deal with situations
as they come up, all of whom are referred

to by male pronouns, even the ones that are
obviously women, which is either abject laziness

or a relevant indictment of small town authorities,
because the plot is about an inexperienced

female deputy in a small town department having
to take over when the sheriff is killed and

who just can&#39;t seem to get respect in a man&#39;s
world.

Fortunately her officers arrest a drifter
who turns out to be a former police chief

wanted on federal corruption charges, but
more importantly he&#39;s a man with a big manly
beard so she puts him in charge instead.

Hey, This Is The Police 2, did you see what
I did there?

I got the premise of your story across in
about half a paragraph.

Perhaps you could show that to your cutscene
writer the next time you get a word in edgeways.

Yes, Titper has pretensions to cinematic storytelling,
but, well.

Here&#39;s my impression of a This Is The Police
2 cutscene.

I mean, I mean, this is me doing an impression
of a This Is The Police 2 cutscene right now.
I&#39;m doing it now.

Can&#39;t you see I&#39;m doing an impression of a
This Is The Police 2 cutscene, viewers?
Viewers?
Viewers?
Are you listening, viewers?

You need to be listening to understand my
impression of a This Is The Police 2 cutscene.

I think they&#39;re going for an ultra-naturalistic
dialogue style, but if realism was the intent,

it fell flat, because realistically if I were
stuck in a conversation like this I&#39;d stick
my head in the nearest bread slicing machine.

Imagine they remade Fargo but every scene
was extended by the ten minutes before the

relevant thing happens and the ten minutes
after it as well.

It&#39;s particularly cruel because the first
thing you do is a tutorial for the turn-based

X-COM style combat and then approximately
ninety-four billion years elapse before you

get to do it for real, and not just because
the cutscenes are all like an argument broke

out at the old folk&#39;s home between the hearing
loss wing and the Alzheimer&#39;s ward.

Turns out the bulk of the gameplay is dispatching
officers to petty crimes and making snap FTL-style
text-based decisions.

Which isn&#39;t unenjoyable, but it is a bit of
a lurch when the combat does come back and

we go to a pitched battle with armed bank
robbers immediately after solving the case

of the schoolboys supergluing their bum cheeks
to a bus shelter.

But that&#39;s everyday police work for you I
guess, and after the first combat mission

I was feeling positive, I stealthily brought
all the baddies in alive with my X-COM chops.

But when I was picking my dudes for the second
combat mission, the game went &quot;Oh by the way

some of these officers hate you, and also
being alive, so they&#39;re not going to do anything
you tell them to do.&quot;
&quot;Oh.

Could you point out in some obvious way which
officers have this characteristic?&quot;
&quot;NO.
Now assemble your team.&quot;

Sure enough I inadvertently picked one of
these loose cannon dudes, who immediately

ran off, shot the first bad guy they saw and
caused the nearby building to disgorge about

twenty gang members like a drug fueled clown
car and all my dudes got dead.

And that&#39;s when I decided I&#39;d had enough of
Titper 2.

It&#39;s one thing to bore my tits off, it&#39;s quite
another to then kick my tits around the garden
with a gameplay system I&#39;d usually kinda enjoy.
Feels like a betrayal.

Like getting cut off in traffic by a character
from Sesame Street.
